Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Government Responses to Network Failures: The Case of the Manufacturing Extension Partnerships

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
While inter-firm networks provide an increasingly important alternative to arm's length transactions in knowledge-intensive industries, they are notoriously difficult to build and maintain. Various hypotheses have been advanced for the sources of such collaboration, suggesting that they derive from cultural, organizational and institutional factors. This research attempts to quantify the relative importance of the factors contributing to the success of collaboration projects by developing and analyzing survey and interview-based indicators of public inputs to network production among small and mid-sized firms -- with a particular focus on their provision through the Manufacturing Extension Partnerships sponsored by the Federal Government.

Intellectual Merit: This research contributes to the literature about the rationale for government intervention to foster innovation in the United States. Government intervention is typically justified as a response to market failure, and represents an effort to make markets more competitive. However, a growing body of literature argues that innovation tends to occur in "collaborative spaces" that are sheltered from market competition. The focus of the research is to examine whether there is a mismatch between the process of innovation and the rationale for innovation policy. The research examines the relative importance of public inputs to network production among small and medium-sized firms in a study of the Manufacturing Extension Partnerships (MEPs) sponsored by the National Institute of Standards and Technology.

Broader Impact: The research produces a publicly available data set that can be used to examine the relationship between government inputs and network production. The results inform a variety of different disciplines, such as economics, sociology and political science. The study also engages and trains graduate students in the research processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Market failures are widely offered as the standard rationale for public participation in private affairs. The ubiquity of this rationale, however, has been questioned in recent years. There is evidence that a focus on market failures alone does not always respond well to the needs of producers in an increasingly decentralized economy in which networks are often as important as markets. That focus can, for instance, obscure the significance of a range of other ways in which federal, state and local actors "bridge" and "broker" ties between the myriad stakeholders in the industrial ecosystem, and in which they – therefore – orient themselves towards the mitigation of “network failures” as well.

 

The funded project, in response, asked whether and how public actors, and public-private partnerships, respond to network failures that impede the effective functioning of cluster-based economic development. It also investigated the possibility that existing administrative data – which is usually examined with an eye towards the ways in which the system might repair market failures – might be exploited in alternative ways to better capture effects of such "network-fixing" activities.

 

The study focused on the National Institute of Science and Manufacturing's (NIST) Manufacturing Extension Partnerships (MEP). The MEP is tasked by congress with improving productivity and technological performance in United States manufacturing through the transfer of technology, techniques and information to US-based small- and medium-sized manufacturing companies. The program has long been expected to orient its activities toward the resolution of market failures. However, the many MEP centers that make up the program are engaged in a variety of other activities as well, many of which are oriented towards the reparation of network failures as well.

 

The research successfully developed means of distinguishing between “network-making” and “market-making” forms of industrial and innovation policy in existing administrative data (i.e. by repurposing data gathered for other purposes). It has shown that MEP centers engage at least to some degree in the mitigation of network failures. In this role, they do not compete with existing consultants or training institutions but serve instead as an essential network facilitator. They also help manufacturers connect with each other and, consequently, engender collaboration and information sharing in manufacturing industries. And, the data suggest, a “network making" industrial and innovation policy focus generates measurably better results than those oriented towards the mitigation of market failures alone.
